title-group.article-title: Processing and properties of soy protein/silica nanocomposites fabricated in situ synthesis

abstract.p: Nanocomposite materials were prepared via glycerol plasticized soy protein as the matrix and in situ fabricated silica as thereinforcing phase. The silica nanoparticles were synthesized in the protein environment by sodium silicate as a precursor. The resulting composites were characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), wide-angle X-ray diffraction (WAXD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA), tensile tests, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The results revealed that silica particles were homogeneously dispersed in soy protein matrix at a nanometer scale with low silica addition (lower than 15%). Silica particles exhibited a high adhesion with protein matrix through hydrogen bonding and confined the motions of soy protein segments. The incorporation of silica as a reinforcing agent significantly improved the mechanical properties and thermal stability of soy protein plastics.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Proteins are one of the three essential macromolecules inthe biological systems and could be easily isolated from natural systems.1 The developments of nonfood applications of plant proteins are receiving tremendous amount of effort now for the growth of environmental concerns.2–8 Soy proteins are mainly storage proteins like many other plant proteins and one of the most important resources with the lowest price among plant proteins.9 Research on soy protein plastics has begun inthe 1940s.1 However, pure soy protein is a poor choice as the replacement of common plastics. It is difficult to process for the high modulus and the brittle and rigid nature without plasticizer addition.1 Glycerol was the most commonly used plasticizer for soy protein. The plasticizing effect of glycerol on the microstructure and properties of soy protein plastics has been intensively studied.10,11 Other plasticizers, such as hydroxylamine,12 amides,13 sorghum wax, sorbitol,14 etc. were also used tofabricate thermoplastic soy protein. Mechanical properties are considered the most important of all theproperties in plastics. The incorporation of nanofillers promotes a more effective pathway to improve the overall mechanical properties of polymers over direct modifications of their molecular composition, due to the strong interfacial interactions and restriction of macromolecular mobility.15,16 For this purpose, different fillers were incorporated in soy protein plastics to improve their performance, such as natural polymer-based nanocrystals or whiskers,17,18 clays,16,19 inorganic fillers,20,21 plant fibers,22 and so on.

Silica has been used in polymeric compounds as an effective reinforcing agent.23,24 Much effort has been made to fabricate polymer/silica nanocomposites by insitu synthesis.25,26 However, the fabrication of silica particles in soy protein matrix has not been reported. With this aim, soy protein/silica composites were prepared through in situ fabrication and the structure and properties of the glycerol plasticized soy protein/silica nanocomposite plastics was studied. The effects of silica on mechanical performance and thermal stability were particularly investigated.

sec.title: Experimental part
sec.p: Materials. Pristine soy protein isolate (SPI) with a protein content of 90.38% was purchased from DuPont-Yunmeng Protein Technology Co. Ltd (Yunmeng, China). Sodium silicate nonahydrate (Na2SiO3·9H2O), hydrochloric acid, acetone, and glycerol were all of analytical grade and purchased from the Shanghai Chemical Co. (Shanghai, China).

sec.title: Preparation of soy protein/silica nanocomposites and plastics
sec.p: The silica nanoparticles were prepared by adapting the precious published procedure with a little modification.27,28 Firstly, desired amount of sodium silicate was dissolved in 200 mL distilled water at ambient temperature with stirring. A total of 10 g SPI was added into the clear NaSiO3 solution and mechanically stirred for 1 h to obtain an emulsion. The pH of the emulsion was adjusted with 2 N HCl solution to 6.5 ± 0.1 detected using a digital pH analyzer (Lida, pHS-25, China). The mixture was left under mild stirring at 30°C for 3 h. After the reaction, 250 mL acetone was added into the resultant emulsion to precipitate the SPI/silica complex. The complex was separated by centrifuging with a speed of 9,000 rpm at 25°C for 15 min, and then the resultant precipitate powder was washed by acetone for three times. Subsequently, the resulting SPI/silica composites were vacuum-dried for 24 h to obtain a yellow nanocomposite powder.

The nanocomposite powders with an addition of 33.3 wt% glycerol (the content of glycerol on total mass of sample) as plasticizer were mixed in a high-speed mixer for 15 min, and then were extruded with a single-screw extruder (PolyDrive with Rheomex R252, ThermoHaake, Germany) with diameter 19.1 mm and length: diameter of 25:1. The screw rotation speed was 40 rpm, and the temperature profile along the extruder barrel was 90, 110, and 120°C (from feed zone to exit). Subsequently, the extrudates were compression-molded at 140°C for 10 min under a pressure of 20 MPa. The plastics were conditioned in a desiccator with P2O5 as desiccant for 1 week at room temperature before characterization.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of the nanocomposite powders were recorded on a Nicolet 5700 spectrometer (Nicolet, USA) in a range of 4000 to 400 cm−1 using a KBr-pellet method with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Wide-angle X-ray diffraction (WAXD) was performed on a D8 Advance diffractometer (Bruker, USA) equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 0.154 nm). The diffraction data were collected from 2θ = 3–60° with a step interval of 0.02° with a scan rate of 4°/min. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed to investigate the morphology of the nanocomposite films. The films were frozen and fractured in liquid nitrogen. The fractured surfaces were sputtered with gold and observed on an SEM (S-570, Hitachi, Ibaraki, Japan) using an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. Dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) was carried out using a dynamic mechanical analyzer (Model Q800, TA Instruments, DE, USA) in tensile mode. Samples were first equilibrated at –100°C for 1 min, and then scanned from –100°C to 180°C at a heating rate of 5°C min−1. The measurements were performed in isochronal conditions at a frequency of 1 Hz. The setup measures the storage tensile modulus E′ and theloss modulus E′′. The ratio between the two components, loss angle tangent, tan δ = E′/E′′, was also determined. The temperature of the peak of the tan δ curve (Ttanδ) was defined as the glass transition temperature (Tg) of the samples. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the SPI/silica nanocomposite plastics was investigated on a STA 499 C instrument (NETZSCH Co., Germany) under a nitrogen atmosphere from 30 to 800°C at a heating rate of 10°C min−1. The tensile strength (σb), elongation at break (εb), and Young’s modulus (E) of the sheets were measured on a universal testing machine (CMT6503, Shenzhen SANS Test Machine Co. Ltd, Shenzhen, China) with a tensile rate of 5 mm min−1 according to ISO527-3:1995 (E). Five parallel measurements were carried out for each sample.

sec.title: FTIR spectroscopy
sec.p:
The FTIR spectra for the soy protein/silica nanocomposite powders are shown in Figure 1. For pure soy protein, the band at 3298.8 cm−1 was the amide A band of protein attributed to the hydrogen-bonded N-H stretching. The weak shoulder at a higher wave number may be attributed to the O-H stretch29 or the ‘free’ N-H stretch30 or both. The symmetrical bands centered about at 1659.8 cm−1 were attributed to the amide І of soy protein ascribed to C = O stretching. The bands at 1531.3 and 1232.8 cm−1 were the amide ІІ and III band resulting from N-H bending coupled with CN stretching.31 The spectrum of the soy protein/silica nanocomposites was characterized by the presence of the absorption bands typical of the pristine protein components. With addition of silica, the amide A and І bands moved to a lower wave number, while the amide ІІ and III band shifted to opposite direction. The changes in the characteristic bands in the spectrum suggested that hydrogen bonding was the underlying mechanism for the shift of absorption peaks. Figure 1.
Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectroscopy of soy protein/silica nanocomposites. The silica contents were labeled in the figure.

The bands assigned to Si-O-Si symmetric and asymmetric vibrations were reported to appear around 109232 and 780 cm−1, respectively, and the Si-O stretching vibration band at 450 cm−1,33–35 with the intensity roughly proportional to the silica content. The Si-O stretching vibration band exhibited a red-shift with an increase of silica content in the nanocomposites. Usually, the forming of hydrogen bonds result in a red-shift of the stretching bands but a blue shift of bending bands. In view of the obvious change of the protein amide absorbance and the Si-O stretching peak, it was believed that the hydrogen bonding existed in the SPI/silica nanocomposites and the hydrogen bonding sites may be the oxygen atoms on the SiO2 and the hydrogen atoms in the peptide bonds.

sec.title: WAXD
sec.p:
Figure 2 shows the WAXD spectra of glycerol plasticized soy protein nanocomposites. Pristine soy protein plastics exhibited two characteristic bump peaks centered at about 9.8 and 19°, suggesting the mainly amorphous state of soy protein. With addition of 5% silica, the intensity and the width at half-maximum intensity of the two peaks decreased. However, the changes of these peaks were not obvious with further increase of silica. The silica particles in all the composites exhibited an amorphous state without any characteristic diffraction peak. Figure 2.
X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of glycerol plasticized soy protein plastics with different amount of silica.

sec.title: Morphology
sec.p:
Unfilled protein film exhibited a smooth surface as shown in Figure 3(a). Addition of 5 wt% silica into the protein matrix led to a coarse surface (Figure 3(b)), indicating a strong interaction between the filler andmatrix. With the increase of silica contents (Figure3(c), (d) and (e)), the composites exhibited increasing concentrations of silica on the fractured surface. Nanosizied silica particles from several to hundreds of nanometers had a uniform distribution in the protein matrix especially for silica content below 15 wt%. It is worth noting that with a low silica content (not higher than 15 wt%), the silica had a strong adhesion with protein matrix and most silica particles were embedded into the matrix. However, with a high silica loading, more and more fillers floated on the fractured surface with little parts of the fillers embedded in the matrix. Moreover, there were also some larger particles present on the fracture surface. It led to a visible decreaseof elongation at break and a brittle property of the composites with higher silica contents, as discussed afterward. Figure 3.
Scanning electron microscopy of the cryo-fractured surfaces of soy protein plastics with 0% (a), 5% (b), 10% (c), 15%, and (d)25% silica.

sec.title: DMTA
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the plots of log (E’) (storage modulus, Figure 4(a)) and tan δ (loss angle tangent, Figure 4(b)) at1 Hz as a function of temperature for glycerol plasticized soy protein plastics with different amount of silica loading. At low temperatures, no obvious difference wasobserved for the storage modulus. For polymers at their glassy state, the modulus could be considered to be dependent of the matrix and independent of the fillers. In this state, molecular motions of soy protein were largely restricted to vibration and short-range rotational motions,36 leading to a high modulus and the silica couldhardly be appreciated as reinforcing filler in this temperature range. In the glass state, the storage modulus decreased slightly with the increase of temperature. Figure 4.
Dependence of logarithm of the storage tensile modulus (a) and loss angle tangent (b) on temperature for glycerol plasticized soy protein/silica nanocomposites.

At higher temperatures, the storage modulus experienced a two-step decrease. Simultaneously, the loss angle tangent curves went through two maximum peaks, corresponding to the two relaxation processes associated with the glass-rubber transition ascribed to glycerol-rich and protein-rich domains labeled as α1 and α2.10 The glass transition temperatures corresponding to α1 and α2 are listed in Table 1. Both the Tα1 and Tα2 increased with the addition of silica, indicating that silica restricted molecular motions of SPI due to the strong hydrogen bond interactions between them.37 The magnitude drops associated with the α1 relaxation process at low temperature were much smaller than those corresponding to the α2 relaxation process at higher temperature. It further confirmed that glycerol plasticized soy protein appeared as a heterogeneous system composed of glycerol-rich domains dispersed in protein-rich matrix domains.10,38 Table 1.

5 457.6 6.970 −35.2 0.1600 91.9 0.3144
10 529.8 12.62 −34.8 0.1504 97.9 0.3100
15 838.4 27.70 −29.9 0.1585 94.9 0.2910

The relaxation magnitude at α1 increases while that at α2 decreases gradually with the increase of silica content. The intensity indicates the mobility of polymer chains inthe systems2 and mainly depends on the magnitude of the modulus drop.37 The effect of silica loading on the peak intensity of loss angle tangent associated with the α1 and α2 relaxation (Iα1 and Iα2) mainly involved: the decrease of relaxing entities (soy protein and glycerol) participating in the relaxation process and the concomitant lowering of the modulus drop due to the reduced molecular mobility of the confined the motions of soy protein segments with the increase of silica content [38], which all led to the decrease of Iα1 and Iα2. However, I should notice that glycerol was added to the samples with a proportion of 33 wt% compared with the mass of the total samples (soy protein and silica). With the increase of silica, the ratio of glycerol to protein may increase. Therefore it may lead to an increase of mobility of polymer chains and the intensity of loss angle tangent associated with the α1 and α2 relaxation. It seems that silica may have a larger confinement on the protein-rich domain. Therefore, the latter phenomenon had a greater effect on α1 relaxation and the former phenomenon was predominant in the α2 relaxation.

For SPI/silica nanocomposites, the two-step storage modulus drop was remarkably reduced, especially for temperatures higher than Tα2. A pronounced increase in storage modulus of composites was found with theincrease of silica content. For example, it could be observed from Table 1 that the modulus of samples with 15% silica (27.7 MPa) was 5 times higher than that of the pristine films without silica (5.9 MPa) at 150°C, while it was only about 2 times at 50°C. The nanosized silica particles exhibited significantly reinforcing effect on glycerol plasticized soy protein plastics. The interactions between soy protein and silica could restrict the molecular motions of protein macromolecules, resulting in the enhancement of storage modulus of the nanocomposite plastics.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p:
The mechanical behavior of glycerol-plasticized soy protein was analyzed at room temperature and Figure5 shows the tensile strength, elongation at break, and Young’s modulus as a function of silica content. The typical curves are plotted in Figure 6. The testing temperature was between the two glass transition temperatures obtained by DMA. Figure 5.
Mechanical properties of glycerol plasticized soy protein/silica nanocomposites conditioned at 0% RH. Figure 6.
Typical stress vs strain curves of soy protein/silica nanocomposite plastics conditioned at 0% RH. The silica contents are indicated in the figure.

Unfilled soy protein plastics exhibited elastic behavior with a high elongation at break. The tensile strength increased quickly at a low strain and showed a neck tendency. The neck did not propagate continuously but producing horizontal stripes along the necked region perpendicular to the direction of the stress. There was not obvious strain hardening before the failure of the sample. The stress then increased gently with the strain until the break of the film. Addition of silica decreases the necking tendency. Plastics with 20% silica exhibit a fragile behavior. The lack of necking phenomenon may be attributed to the homogeneous nature of composites at a scale of a few hundred nm.39

Elongation at break decreases with the increase of silica content as expected. With silica content less than15%, the diminution seemed to be linear. However, the negative effect on strain appeared to plateau at higher silica concentrations (more than 15%). The tensile strength enhanced with the increase of silica. The Young’s modulus exhibited a more pronounced increase. The modulus increased almost linear to 508.43 MPa with 15% silica content from 285.31 MPa for unfilled glycerol plasticized soy protein. The modulus values were far lower than those obtained by DMA tests. It should be the result of that the DMA tests only apply weak stress on samples and the adhesion between filler and matrix was not involved.40

sec.title: Thermal stability
sec.p:
TGA is used to characterize the decomposition and thermal stability of materials and to examine the kinetics of the physicochemical processes occurring in the sample.41 The weight loss traces and their differential curves as a function of temperature are shown in Figure 7. Silica was thermally stable in the testing temperature range. The weight loss between room temperature and 120°C was attributed to the water absorbed in soy protein plastics. The weight loss in the temperature range of 120–280°C was mainly related to the evaporation of glycerol. When the temperature was higher than 280°C, soy protein degraded. Figure 7.
TG and DTG curves of glycerol plasticized soy protein/silica nanocomposite plastics.

Temperatures at the maximum rate of weight loss determined by the peak of the DTG curves corresponding to glycerol release and protein degradation were noted as Tmax, 1 and Tmax, 2 and are listed in Table 2. Clearly, the temperatures of the maximum weight-loss rate of the nanocomposites rose largely compared to those of unfilled glycerol plasticized soy protein. Compared with unfilled soy protein, the residue weight after the whole thermo-degradation period of soy protein was much higher for composites with silica loading. Temperatures at a weight loss of 10% (T10%) are also listed in Table 2. The temperatures increased with the increase of silica in the matrix. Usually, the time at a weight loss of 10% at a certain temperature is defined as lifetime.41 I could conclude that the lifetime would be highly extended for the increase of T10%. Also, the temperatures at a weight loss of 50% (T50%) exhibited an obvious enhancement with the silica incorporation. Table 2.

The area under a DTG curve is proportional to the mass change and the height of the peak at any temperature gives the rate of mass change at that temperature.42 With addition of silica, the area under the DTG curves and the peak height for the two processes (glycerol release and protein degradation) both weakened. Silica could form hydrogen bonds with soy protein matrix and confine the segment motion, which could enhance the thermal stability of the resulted nanocomposites. For glycerol release temperature, the weight loss and the rate decreased due to the hydrogen bonds formed between silica and the matrix. For protein degradation temperature range, the decrease of weight loss and the velocity was partly attributed to the reduction of protein content with addition of silica, besides the effect of hydrogen bonds between protein and silica.

The activation energy of polymer decomposition, Ea, could be calculated from the TGA curves by the integral method using the following Equation43: (1) where α is the decomposed fraction, T is the absolute temperature, θ is (T − Tmax), and R is the gas constant. From the plots of ln[ln(1 − α)−1] vs. θ, Ea could be determined from the slopes of the straight lines. The calculated activation energies of different processes are displayed in Table 2. Ea, 1 and Ea, 2 of the silica-filled plastics were lowered compared with unfilled glycerol plasticized soy protein plastics. Silicon dioxide has a much lower molecular weight compared with soy protein (with a weight-average molecular weight of 2.05 × 105),44 therefore, the addition of silica into protein matrix would decrease the molar concentration of glycerol and protein in the total sample, which lowered the activation energy although the thermal stability of the nanocomposites was enhanced.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Nanocomposites were developed by in situ fabricating silica in soy protein isolate matrix with glycerol as plasticizer. The silica was synthesized in the protein environment by sodium silicate as a precursor. The structures and properties of the resulting nanocomposites strongly depended on the content of silica. Silica particles had a uniform distribution in the protein matrix. The glass transition temperatures associated with glycerol-rich and protein-rich domains were observed to increase with addition of silica, indicating that silica restricted molecular motions of soy protein molecules due to the strong hydrogen bond interaction between them. The two-step storage tensile modulus drop was remarkably reduced with addition of silica. Elongation at break decreased with the increase of silica while the tensile strength enhanced. The Young’s modulus exhibited a more pronounced increase. Temperatures at the maximum rate of weight loss determined by the peak of theDTG curves corresponding to glycerol release and protein degradation were largely enhanced by adding silica. The mass change and the rate of mass change at the two peak temperature also weakened. All the results revealed that silica particles acted as effective reinforcing filler and improved the mechanical and thermal properties significantly.
